pairs.stoic_text:
The good emperor was not spared domestic troubles. Faustina had borne
him several children, of whom he was passionately fond. Their innocent
faces may still be seen in many a sculpture gallery, recalling with odd
effect the dreamy countenance of their father. But they died one by
one, and when Marcus came to his own end only one of his sons still
lived--the weak and worthless Commodus. On his father's death Commodus,
who succeeded him, undid the work of many campaigns by a hasty and
unwise peace; and his reign of twelve years proved him to be a ferocious
and bloodthirsty tyrant. Scandal has made free with the name of Faustina
herself, who is accused not only of unfaithfulness, but of intriguing
with Cassius and egging him on to his fatal rebellion, it must be
admitted that these charges rest on no sure evidence; and the emperor,
at all events, loved her dearly, nor ever felt the slightest qualm of
suspicion.
pairs.neutral_text:
The good emperor had problems at home too. Faustina gave birth to several children, and he loved them deeply. You can still see their young faces in sculpture collections today, and they look remarkably similar to their father. However, the children died one after another. By the time Marcus died, only one son remained alive - Commodus, who was weak and worthless. When Commodus became emperor after his father's death, he quickly made a poorly thought-out peace agreement that destroyed the results of many military campaigns. He ruled for twelve years and proved to be a cruel and violent dictator. 

Rumors also targeted Faustina herself. People accused her of being unfaithful to her husband and of plotting with Cassius to encourage his doomed rebellion. However, these accusations have no solid proof. The emperor loved her greatly and never doubted her loyalty.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXVIII. Remember, that that which sets a man at work, and hath power
over the affections to draw them either one way, or the other way, is
not any external thing properly, but that which is hidden within every
man's dogmata, and opinions: That, that is rhetoric; that is life; that
(to speak true) is man himself. As for thy body, which as a vessel, or
a case, compasseth thee about, and the many and curious instruments
that it hath annexed unto it, let them not trouble thy thoughts. For
of themselves they are but as a carpenter's axe, but that they are born
with us, and naturally sticking unto us. But otherwise, without the
inward cause that hath power to move them, and to restrain them, those
parts are of themselves of no more use unto us, than the shuttle is
of itself to the weaver, or the pen to the writer, or the whip to the
coachman.
pairs.neutral_text:
38. Remember that what motivates a person and influences their emotions is not external circumstances, but their own beliefs and opinions that exist inside their mind. These internal beliefs are what truly control behavior and define who a person really is.

Don't let your physical body and its abilities distract you from this truth. Your body is just a container, and its parts are like tools - similar to how a carpenter has an axe. The difference is that we're born with our body parts attached to us. However, without the internal mental force that controls and directs them, our body parts are useless on their own. They're no different from a weaver's shuttle, a writer's pen, or a driver's whip - just tools that need someone to operate them.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXVI. Whatsoever doth happen in the world, is, in the course of nature,
as usual and ordinary as a rose in the spring, and fruit in summer. Of
the same nature is sickness and death; slander, and lying in wait, and
whatsoever else ordinarily doth unto fools use to be occasion either
of joy or sorrow. That, whatsoever it is, that comes after, doth always
very naturally, and as it were familiarly, follow upon that which was
before. For thou must consider the things of the world, not as a loose
independent number, consisting merely of necessary events; but as a
discreet connection of things orderly and harmoniously disposed. There
is then to be seen in the things of the world, not a bare succession,
but an admirable correspondence and affinity.
pairs.neutral_text:
36. Everything that happens in the world is natural and normal, just like roses blooming in spring or fruit growing in summer. This includes sickness, death, criticism, and deception - all the things that typically make foolish people happy or sad. Whatever happens next naturally follows from what happened before. 

You should think of world events not as random occurrences or just necessary things that must happen, but as connected parts of an organized system. When you look at things this way, you don't just see one event after another - you see how things relate to and influence each other.

pairs.stoic_text:
Stoics, a philosophic system founded by Zeno (4th century B.C.), and
systematised by Chrysippus (3rd century B.C.). Their physical theory
was a pantheistic materialism, their summum bonum "to live according
to nature." Their wise man needs nothing, he is sufficient to himself;
virtue is good, vice bad, external things indifferent.
pairs.neutral_text:
Stoicism is a philosophical system started by Zeno in the 4th century B.C. and organized into a complete system by Chrysippus in the 3rd century B.C. 

The Stoics believed that everything in the universe was made of matter and that God was present in all things. They thought the highest goal in life was to live in harmony with nature.

According to Stoic teaching, an ideal wise person does not depend on anything external and can meet all their own needs. Stoics considered virtue to be good and vice to be bad. They viewed everything else - such as wealth, health, or social status - as neither good nor bad, but neutral.

pairs.stoic_text:
XLIV. Dost thou grieve that thou dost weigh but so many pounds, and not
three hundred rather? Just as much reason hast thou to grieve that
thou must live but so many years, and not longer. For as for bulk and
substance thou dost content thyself with that proportion of it that is
allotted unto thee, so shouldst thou for time.
pairs.neutral_text: 44. Do you feel sad that you weigh only a certain number of pounds instead of three hundred? You have just as much reason to feel sad that you will live only a certain number of years instead of living longer. Just as you accept the amount of physical matter your body contains, you should also accept the amount of time you have been given.

pairs.stoic_text:
XIII "Patient hearing... He would not" (16). C. translates his
conjectural reading epimonon ollan. on proapsth Stich suggests a reading
with much the same sense: .....epimonon all antoi "Strict and rigid
dealing" (16). C. translates tonvn (Pal. MS.) as though from tonoz,
in the sense of "strain." "rigour." The reading of other MSS. tonvn is
preferable.
pairs.neutral_text:
**Section XIII**

**"Patient hearing... He would not" (line 16):** C. translates a text that he has guessed might read "epimonon ollan. on proapsth." Stich proposes a different reading with similar meaning: "epimonon all antoi."

**"Strict and rigid dealing" (line 16):** C. translates "tonvn" (from the Palatine manuscript) as if it comes from "tonoz," meaning "strain" or "rigour." However, the reading "tonvn" found in other manuscripts is better.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXI. To live with the Gods. He liveth with the Gods, who at all times
affords unto them the spectacle of a soul, both contented and well
pleased with whatsoever is afforded, or allotted unto her; and
performing whatsoever is pleasing to that Spirit, whom (being part of
himself) Jove hath appointed to every man as his overseer and governor.
pairs.neutral_text:
**21. Living with the Gods**

A person lives with the gods when they consistently show the gods a soul that is satisfied and happy with whatever they receive or whatever happens to them. They also do whatever pleases the divine spirit that Jupiter has assigned to each person as their guide and ruler - this spirit being a part of Jupiter himself.

pairs.stoic_text:
XII. Whatsoever any man either doth or saith, thou must be good; not for
any man's sake, but for thine own nature's sake; as if either gold, or
the emerald, or purple, should ever be saying to themselves, Whatsoever
any man either doth or saith, I must still be an emerald, and I must
keep my colour.
pairs.neutral_text: 12. No matter what other people do or say, you should continue being a good person. Don't do this to please others, but because being good is part of your essential nature. This is like how gold stays gold, an emerald stays green, and purple fabric stays purple, regardless of what happens around them. They don't change their basic qualities because of external circumstances, and neither should you change your moral character.

pairs.stoic_text:
XLIII. When thou wilt comfort and cheer thyself, call to mind the
several gifts and virtues of them, whom thou dost daily converse with;
as for example, the industry of the one; the modesty of another; the
liberality of a third; of another some other thing. For nothing can so
much rejoice thee, as the resemblances and parallels of several virtues,
visible and eminent in the dispositions of those who live with thee;
especially when, all at once, as near as may be, they represent
themselves unto thee. And therefore thou must have them always in a
readiness.
pairs.neutral_text: When you want to feel better about yourself, think about the good qualities of the people you spend time with every day. For example, notice how hardworking one person is, how humble another person is, how generous a third person is, and identify other positive traits in others. Nothing will make you happier than observing these various good qualities in the people around you, especially when you can see multiple virtues at the same time. Therefore, you should keep these observations ready in your mind.

pairs.stoic_text:
XL. Whatsoever in any kind doth happen to any one, is expedient to the
whole. And thus much to content us might suffice, that it is expedient
for the whole in general. But yet this also shalt thou generally
perceive, if thou dost diligently take heed, that whatsoever doth happen
to any one man or men.... And now I am content that the word expedient,
should more generally be understood of those things which we otherwise
call middle things, or things indifferent; as health, wealth, and the
like.
pairs.neutral_text: Whatever happens to any person serves the benefit of the whole system. This fact alone should be enough to satisfy us - that individual events benefit the overall whole. You will also notice this pattern generally if you pay close attention to what happens to any person or group of people. I want the word "expedient" to be understood broadly here, including things we normally consider neutral or indifferent, such as health, wealth, and similar circumstances.

pairs.stoic_text:
XI. When thou art hard to be stirred up and awaked out of thy sleep,
admonish thyself and call to mind, that, to perform actions tending to
the common good is that which thine own proper constitution, and
that which the nature of man do require. But to sleep, is common to
unreasonable creatures also. And what more proper and natural, yea what
more kind and pleasing, than that which is according to nature?
pairs.neutral_text: 11. When you have trouble getting out of bed in the morning, remind yourself that doing things that benefit society is what you're designed for as a human being. Sleep is something that even animals do. What could be more natural and satisfying than doing what you're meant to do?

pairs.stoic_text:
XIII. What use is there of suspicion at all? or, why should thoughts
of mistrust, and suspicion concerning that which is future, trouble thy
mind at all? What now is to be done, if thou mayest search and inquiry
into that, what needs thou care for more? And if thou art well able to
perceive it alone, let no man divert thee from it. But if alone thou
doest not so well perceive it, suspend thine action, and take advice
from the best. And if there be anything else that doth hinder thee, go
on with prudence and discretion, according to the present occasion
and opportunity, still proposing that unto thyself, which thou doest
conceive most right and just. For to hit that aright, and to speed in
the prosecution of it, must needs be happiness, since it is that only
which we can truly and properly be said to miss of, or miscarry in.
pairs.neutral_text: **XIII.** Why be suspicious or worry about future uncertainties? Focus on what needs to be done now. If you can figure it out by yourself, don't let others distract you. If you can't solve it alone, pause and ask for advice from knowledgeable people. If other obstacles exist, proceed carefully based on current circumstances while aiming for what seems most right and fair. Success comes from identifying the correct course of action and following through with it, since this is the only thing you can truly succeed or fail at.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXIV. What doest thou desire? To live long. What? To enjoy the
operations of a sensitive soul; or of the appetitive faculty? or wouldst
thou grow, and then decrease again? Wouldst thou long be able to talk,
to think and reason with thyself? Which of all these seems unto thee a
worthy object of thy desire? Now if of all these thou doest find that
they be but little worth in themselves, proceed on unto the last, which
is, in all things to follow God and reason. But for a man to grieve that
by death he shall be deprived of any of these things, is both against
God and reason.
pairs.neutral_text: **24. What do you want? To live a long life. But what does that actually mean? Do you want to keep using your senses, or satisfy your desires? Do you want to keep growing and then aging? Do you want to keep talking, thinking, and reasoning? Which of these things is really worth wanting? If you realize that none of these things are particularly valuable on their own, then focus on what matters most: following God and using reason in everything you do. It goes against both God and reason to feel upset that death will take these things away from you.**

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXV. To suffer change can be no hurt; as no benefit it is, by change to
attain to being. The age and time of the world is as it were a flood and
swift current, consisting of the things that are brought to pass in
the world. For as soon as anything hath appeared, and is passed away,
another succeeds, and that also will presently out of sight.
pairs.neutral_text: 35. Being changed cannot harm you, just as gaining existence through change is not necessarily beneficial. The world's timeline is like a fast-moving river made up of events that happen. As soon as something appears and then disappears, something else takes its place, and that too will quickly vanish from view.

pairs.stoic_text:
XVII. So live as indifferent to the world and all worldly objects, as
one who liveth by himself alone upon some desert hill. For whether here,
or there, if the whole world be but as one town, it matters not much for
the place. Let them behold and see a man, that is a man indeed, living
according to the true nature of man. If they cannot bear with me, let
them kill me. For better were it to die, than so to live as they would
have thee.
pairs.neutral_text: **XVII.** Live without being overly concerned about society and material things, like someone living alone on a remote mountain. Whether you're here or somewhere else doesn't matter much, since the whole world is like one community anyway. Let people see someone who lives authentically according to human nature. If they can't tolerate this, they can kill you. It's better to die than to live the way others expect you to live against your principles.

pairs.stoic_text:
VI. These things thou must always have in mind: What is the nature
of the universe, and what is mine--in particular: This unto that what
relation it hath: what kind of part, of what kind of universe it is: And
that there is nobody that can hinder thee, but that thou mayest always
both do and speak those things which are agreeable to that nature,
whereof thou art a part.
pairs.neutral_text: **VI.** Always remember these points: What is the nature of the universe, and what is my own nature. Specifically, consider how these two relate to each other - what kind of part am I within what kind of whole system. Remember that no one can prevent you from acting and speaking in ways that align with the nature of which you are a part.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXII. Be not angry neither with him whose breath, neither with him whose
arm holes, are offensive. What can he do? such is his breath naturally,
and such are his arm holes; and from such, such an effect, and such
a smell must of necessity proceed. 'O, but the man (sayest thou) hath
understanding in him, and might of himself know, that he by standing
near, cannot choose but offend.' And thou also (God bless thee!) hast
understanding. Let thy reasonable faculty, work upon his reasonable
faculty; show him his fault, admonish him. If he hearken unto thee, thou
hast cured him, and there will be no more occasion of anger.
pairs.neutral_text: **22.** Don't get angry with people who have bad breath or body odor. They can't help it - that's just how their body naturally smells, and bad odors are bound to happen with those conditions. You might say, "But that person has a brain and should realize they're bothering others by standing close to people." Well, you have a brain too. Use your intelligence to appeal to their intelligence: point out the problem and give them advice. If they listen to you, you'll have solved the issue and won't need to be angry anymore.

pairs.stoic_text:
XLI. As the ordinary shows of the theatre and of other such places,
when thou art presented with them, affect thee; as the same things still
seen, and in the same fashion, make the sight ingrateful and tedious;
so must all the things that we see all our life long affect us. For all
things, above and below, are still the same, and from the same causes.
When then will there be an end?
pairs.neutral_text: 41. When you watch theater performances and other entertainment, they affect you at first. But when you see the same things repeatedly in the same way, the experience becomes unpleasant and boring. This same principle applies to everything we encounter throughout our lives. All things, whether important or trivial, remain essentially the same and result from the same underlying causes. So when will this cycle end?

pairs.stoic_text:
XXVII. Within a while the earth shall cover us all, and then she herself
shall have her change. And then the course will be, from one period of
eternity unto another, and so a perpetual eternity. Now can any man
that shall consider with himself in his mind the several rollings or
successions of so many changes and alterations, and the swiftness of all
these rulings; can he otherwise but contemn in his heart and despise
all worldly things? The cause of the universe is as it were a strong
torrent, it carrieth all away.
pairs.neutral_text: In a short time, the earth will cover all of us when we die. Then the earth itself will change. This process continues from one eternal period to another, creating endless eternity. If someone thinks about all these cycles of change and how quickly everything moves, they will naturally look down on material possessions and worldly concerns. The force that drives the universe is like a powerful river current that sweeps everything along with it.

pairs.stoic_text:
IX. In the mind that is once truly disciplined and purged, thou canst
not find anything, either foul or impure, or as it were festered:
nothing that is either servile, or affected: no partial tie; no
malicious averseness; nothing obnoxious; nothing concealed. The life of
such an one, death can never surprise as imperfect; as of an actor, that
should die before he had ended, or the play itself were at an end, a man
might speak.
pairs.neutral_text: IX. When your mind is properly trained and cleansed, you won't find anything corrupt, dirty, or infected in it. There will be nothing submissive or fake, no biased attachments, no spiteful rejections, nothing objectionable, and nothing hidden. Death can never catch such a person with an incomplete life, unlike an actor who dies before finishing their performance or before the play ends.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXV. Fit and accommodate thyself to that estate and to those
occurrences, which by the destinies have been annexed unto thee; and
love those men whom thy fate it is to live with; but love them truly. An
instrument, a tool, an utensil, whatsoever it be, if it be fit for the
purpose it was made for, it is as it should be though he perchance that
made and fitted it, be out of sight and gone. But in things natural,
that power which hath framed and fitted them, is and abideth within them
still: for which reason she ought also the more to be respected, and we
are the more obliged (if we may live and pass our time according to her
purpose and intention) to think that all is well with us, and according
to our own minds. After this manner also, and in this respect it is,
that he that is all in all doth enjoy his happiness.
pairs.neutral_text:
**35.** Accept your life circumstances and the events that happen to you, since these are determined by fate. Genuinely care about the people you must live with.

When a tool or instrument works properly for its intended purpose, it functions correctly even if its maker is no longer present. However, natural things are different because the force that created them continues to exist within them. For this reason, we should respect this natural force more. If we live according to nature's plan, we should consider our situation satisfactory and aligned with our preferences. This is how someone who is complete in every way experiences contentment.

pairs.stoic_text:
XIV. What is εὐδαιμονία, or happiness: but ἀγαθὸς δαίμων, or, a good
dæmon, or spirit? What then dost thou do here, O opinion? By the Gods
I adjure thee, that thou get thee gone, as thou earnest: for I need thee
not. Thou earnest indeed unto me according to thy ancient wonted manner.
It is that, that all men have ever been subject unto. That thou camest
therefore I am not angry with thee, only begone, now that I have found
thee what thou art.
pairs.neutral_text:
**XIV. What is happiness?**

Happiness means having a good spirit or inner guide. So why are you here, mistaken thoughts? I'm asking you seriously to leave the same way you came, because I don't need you. You came to me in your usual way, which is something all people experience. I'm not angry that you came - that's normal - but now go away, since I understand what you really are.

pairs.stoic_text:
The Stoics regarded speculation as a means to an end and that end was,
as Zeno put it, to live consistently (ὁμολογουμένος ζῆν), or as it was
later explained, to live in conformity with nature (ὁμολογουμένος τῇ
φύσει ζῆν). This conforming of the life to nature was the Stoic idea of
Virtue. This dictum might easily be taken to mean that virtue consists
in yielding to each natural impulse; but that was very far from the
Stoic meaning. In order to live in accord with nature, it is necessary
to know what nature is; and to this end a threefold division of
philosophy is made—into _Physics_, dealing with the universe and its
laws, the problems of divine government and teleology; _Logic_, which
trains the mind to discern true from false; and _Ethics_, which applies
the knowledge thus gained and tested to practical life.
pairs.neutral_text:
The Stoics viewed philosophical thinking as a tool to achieve a specific goal. According to Zeno, this goal was to live consistently, or as later Stoics explained it, to live in agreement with nature. The Stoics believed that living according to nature was what virtue meant.

This idea could be misunderstood to mean that people should follow every natural urge they have, but that is not what the Stoics meant. To live according to nature, a person must first understand what nature actually is. For this reason, the Stoics divided philosophy into three parts:

1. Physics - the study of the universe, its laws, divine rule, and purpose
2. Logic - training the mind to tell the difference between truth and falsehood  
3. Ethics - using the knowledge gained from physics and logic in everyday life

pairs.stoic_text:
III. Alexander, Caius, Pompeius; what are these to Diogenes, Heraclitus,
and Socrates? These penetrated into the true nature of things; into all
causes, and all subjects: and upon these did they exercise their power
and authority. But as for those, as the extent of their error was, so
far did their slavery extend.
pairs.neutral_text: 3. Alexander, Caius, and Pompeius - what do they matter compared to Diogenes, Heraclitus, and Socrates? The philosophers understood the real nature of things, their causes, and their subjects. This gave them true power and control. The political leaders, however, were enslaved by their mistakes to the same degree that they made those mistakes.

pairs.stoic_text:
X. As several members in one body united, so are reasonable creatures
in a body divided and dispersed, all made and prepared for one common
operation. And this thou shalt apprehend the better, if thou shalt use
thyself often to say to thyself, I am μέλος, or a member of the mass and
body of reasonable substances. But if thou shalt say I am μέρος, or
a part, thou dost not yet love men from thy heart. The joy that thou
takest in the exercise of bounty, is not yet grounded upon a due
ratiocination and right apprehension of the nature of things. Thou dost
exercise it as yet upon this ground barely, as a thing convenient and
fitting; not, as doing good to thyself, when thou dost good unto others.
pairs.neutral_text: **X.** Just as different parts work together in one body, rational beings are scattered but designed to work toward a common purpose. You will understand this better if you regularly remind yourself: "I am a member of the community of rational beings." But if you think of yourself as just a separate part, you don't truly love other people yet. If you enjoy being generous only because it seems like the right thing to do, you haven't fully understood how things really work. You're being generous just because it appears proper, not because you realize that helping others actually benefits you too.

pairs.stoic_text:
Cynics, a school of philosophers, founded by Antisthenes. Their texts
were a kind of caricature of Socraticism. Nothing was good but virtue,
nothing bad but vice. The Cynics repudiated all civil and social claims,
and attempted to return to what they called a state of nature. Many of
them were very disgusting in their manners.
pairs.neutral_text: The Cynics were a group of philosophers started by Antisthenes. Their writings were an exaggerated version of Socratic philosophy. They believed that only virtue was good and only vice was bad. The Cynics rejected all government and social obligations and tried to live in what they considered a natural state. Many of them behaved in ways that people found offensive.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXII. What a subject, and what a course of life is it, that thou doest
so much desire to be rid of. For all these things, what are they, but
fit objects for an understanding, that beholdeth everything according to
its true nature, to exercise itself upon? Be patient, therefore, until
that (as a strong stomach that turns all things into his own nature; and
as a great fire that turneth in flame and light, whatsoever thou doest
cast into it) thou have made these things also familiar, and as it were
natural unto thee.
pairs.neutral_text: **32.** Why do you want to escape from your life and circumstances so badly? All of these experiences are just opportunities for your mind to practice understanding things as they really are. Be patient until you can handle these situations naturally, like a strong stomach that can digest anything, or like a large fire that burns up whatever you throw into it.

pairs.stoic_text:
'I have a serious grievance against you, my dear master, yet indeed my
grief is more than my grievance, because after so long a time I neither
embraced you nor spoke to you, though you visited the palace, and the
moment after I had left the prince my brother. I reproached my brother
severely for not recalling me; nor durst he deny the fault.' Fronto
again writes on one occasion: 'I have seen your daughter. It was like
seeing you and Faustina in infancy, so much that is charming her face
has taken from each of yours.' Or again, at a later date:[41] I have seen
your chicks, most delightful sight that ever I saw in my life, so like
you that nothing is more like than the likeness.... By the mercy of
Heaven they have a healthy colour and strong lungs. One held a piece of
white bread, like a little prince, the other a common piece, like a true
philosophers son.'
pairs.neutral_text:
I am upset with you, my teacher, but I'm more sad than angry because it has been a long time since we hugged or talked, even though you came to the palace right after I had left my brother the prince. I criticized my brother harshly for not calling me back, and he couldn't deny that he was wrong.

Fronto writes another time: "I saw your daughter. She looked like you and Faustina when you were babies, because her face has inherited attractive features from both of you."

Later, he writes: "I saw your children, the most wonderful sight I have ever seen in my life. They look so much like you that nothing could be more similar. Thank God they look healthy and have strong voices. One was holding white bread like a little prince, and the other was holding ordinary bread like the true son of a philosopher."

pairs.stoic_text:
XLIII. When thou hast done well, and another is benefited by thy action,
must thou like a very fool look for a third thing besides, as that
it may appear unto others also that thou hast done well, or that thou
mayest in time, receive one good turn for another? No man useth to be
weary of that which is beneficial unto him. But every action according
to nature, is beneficial. Be not weary then of doing that which is
beneficial unto thee, whilst it is so unto others.
pairs.neutral_text: When you do something good that helps another person, don't expect additional rewards like recognition from others or future favors in return. People don't get tired of things that benefit them. Actions that follow natural principles are beneficial. Therefore, don't get tired of doing things that benefit you when they also benefit others.

pairs.stoic_text:
XLII. This time that is now present, bestow thou upon thyself. They that
rather hunt for fame after death, do not consider, that those men that
shall be hereafter, will be even such, as these whom now they can so
hardly bear with. And besides they also will be mortal men. But to
consider the thing in itself, if so many with so many voices, shall make
such and such a sound, or shall have such and such an opinion concerning
thee, what is it to thee?
pairs.neutral_text: 42. Focus on the present moment and give your attention to yourself right now. People who seek fame after they die don't realize that future generations will have the same flaws as the people living today, whom they already find difficult to tolerate. Also, those future people will be mortal just like everyone else. When you think about it logically, what does it matter to you if many people make noise about you or have opinions about you?
